crop_info.name: Coffee
crop_info.scientific_name: Coffea arabica L. / Coffea canephora Pierre ex Froehner

ideal_climate.soil: Deep, well-drained, loamy or sandy loam, rich in organic matter, pH 5.5-6.5
ideal_climate.shade: Partial shade is beneficial for Arabica, less critical for Robusta

crop_info.economic_importance: Major global commodity, provides income and employment, second most traded commodity after oil.

lifecycle_phases.description: Germination of seeds and initial growth of seedlings in a protected environment. This phase is critical for establishing healthy planting material.

procedures.details: Select ripe, healthy cherries. Pulp, ferment for 24-36 hours, wash, and dry parchment. Use seeds from selected, high-yielding, disease-resistant mother plants. Seeds should be less than 6 months old for optimal germination.
procedures.irrigation: Maintain optimal moisture in germination beds, avoid waterlogging.
procedures.pest_management: Monitor for soil-borne pests like root-grubs and nematodes. Use neem cake (200g/m²) in nursery beds.

procedures.details: Prepare raised beds (1.2m wide, convenient length) with a well-drained mixture of soil, sand, and compost/farmyard manure in a 2:1:1 ratio. Incorporate soil solarization for 4-6 weeks before sowing to control soil-borne pathogens and pests.
procedures.irrigation: Water beds thoroughly before sowing.
procedures.pest_management: Soil solarization is a key preventive measure.

procedures.details: Sow seeds evenly spaced (2-3cm apart) at a depth of 1-1.5 cm in germination beds. Sowing is typically done during the onset of the rainy season.
procedures.irrigation: Light watering after sowing.
procedures.pest_management: Monitor for damping-off disease.

procedures.details: Germination takes 4-8 weeks. Cover beds with straw or polythene sheets to maintain humidity until germination. Remove cover gradually once seedlings emerge. Maintain a humid environment but ensure good ventilation.
procedures.irrigation: Sprinkle water gently, twice daily if needed, to keep the topsoil moist.
procedures.pest_management: Spray Mancozeb (0.2%) or Copper Oxychloride (0.3%) at the first sign of damping-off.

procedures.details: Once seedlings develop 2-4 true leaves (approx. 3-4 months old), transplant them into polythene bags (20x30 cm) filled with a fortified soil mixture (e.g., 3 parts soil, 1 part sand, 2 parts compost/FYM, 100g neem cake, 50g single superphosphate per bag).
procedures.npk_dose: Base application in bags: DAP @ 10g/bag, Potash @ 5g/bag. Incorporate into soil mixture.
procedures.irrigation: Water immediately after transplanting. Maintain consistent moisture.
procedures.pest_management: Monitor for cutworms and white grubs. Apply Chlorpyriphos granules (2-3g/bag) if infestation is observed.

procedures.details: Provide adequate shade (50-60%) using shade nets or natural shade. Gradually reduce shade intensity as seedlings mature to acclimatize them.
procedures.irrigation: Water as required to keep bags moist.
procedures.pest_management: Regularly scout for aphid and mealybug infestations. Use neem oil (1%) or dimethoate (0.05%) for control.

procedures.details: Apply liquid fertilizer (e.g., 19:19:19) at 0.2% concentration every fortnight from the second month after bagging.
procedures.irrigation: Apply after a light shower or watering.
procedures.pest_management: Watch for symptoms of nutrient deficiencies. Apply micronutrient mixtures if needed.

procedures.details: Harden seedlings for 3-4 weeks by gradually exposing them to full sunlight and reducing watering before field planting. Select seedlings of uniform size and free from pests and diseases.
procedures.irrigation: Reduce watering frequency to encourage root development.
procedures.pest_management: Final inspection for any pest/disease issues before dispatch.

preventive_tips: Ensure good drainage in nursery beds and bags.

lifecycle_phases.description: Period of active growth, establishment of the root system, and development of new shoots and leaves post-planting. This phase determines the future potential of the plant.

procedures.details: Plant seedlings at recommended spacing (e.g., 2.5m x 2.5m for Arabica, 2.5m x 3.0m for Robusta) during the onset of monsoon. Dig pits of 45x45x45 cm. Mix topsoil with 10-15 kg FYM/compost, 250g neem cake, and 100g SSP.
procedures.npk_dose: Base application in pits: DAP @ 100g/pit, Potash @ 50g/pit.
procedures.irrigation: Water immediately after planting. Provide supplemental irrigation if monsoon is weak.
procedures.pest_management: Monitor for white ants (termites) and apply Chlorpyriphos (20 ml in 1 L water) around the pit base.

procedures.details: Maintain a weed-free environment around the plant base during the first 3-4 years. Use manual weeding, mulching with organic matter, or judicious use of herbicides. Inter-cultivation is also beneficial.
procedures.irrigation: Weed control helps conserve soil moisture.
procedures.pest_management: Watch for specific weeds that might harbor pests or diseases.

procedures.details: Implement structural pruning for young plants to develop a strong frame. Remove unwanted suckers and epicormic shoots. For established plants, implement handling to regulate growth and airflow.
procedures.irrigation: Proper pruning can improve water and nutrient distribution.
procedures.pest_management: Pruning wounds can be entry points for diseases. Treat wounds with a fungicide paste (e.g., Copper Oxychloride).

procedures.details: Apply FYM/compost (10-15 kg/plant) annually. Apply NPK (e.g., 40:20:40 g NPK per plant per year for 1st year, increasing gradually) in two splits: pre-monsoon and post-monsoon.
procedures.npk_dose: Year 1: 40g N, 20g P2O5, 40g K2O per plant. Split application.
procedures.irrigation: Apply fertilizers before or with irrigation to facilitate uptake.
procedures.pest_management: Balanced nutrition enhances plant vigor and pest resistance.

procedures.details: Provide supplemental irrigation during dry spells, especially in the first few years. Ensure adequate soil moisture for optimal growth without waterlogging.
procedures.irrigation: Schedule irrigation based on soil moisture status, typically 2-3 times per week during dry periods.
procedures.pest_management: Over-watering can promote root rot. Ensure good drainage.

procedures.details: For Arabica, maintain optimal shade levels (30-40% canopy cover) using appropriate shade trees (e.g., Silver Oak, Ficus species). Adjust shade based on the age of the coffee plants and climatic conditions.
procedures.irrigation: Shade trees compete for water; manage irrigation accordingly.
procedures.pest_management: Certain shade trees can host beneficial insects or pests. Monitor their health.

procedures.details: Regularly scout for pests like white stem borer, green scale, mealybugs, and leaf miners. Implement integrated pest management (IPM) strategies.
procedures.irrigation: Healthy plants are less susceptible to pests.
procedures.pest_management: Apply recommended insecticides like Imidacloprid (0.05%) for sucking pests, or systemic insecticides for borers, only when pest levels exceed economic thresholds.

procedures.details: Monitor for early signs of diseases like coffee leaf rust and bacterial blights. Maintain plant health through proper nutrition and sanitation.
procedures.irrigation: Avoid overhead irrigation, which can favor leaf diseases. Drip irrigation is preferred.
procedures.pest_management: Prompt removal of infected plant parts. Preventive fungicide sprays as recommended.

preventive_tips: Maintain soil health and adequate drainage.

lifecycle_phases.description: The phase where coffee plants produce fragrant white flowers, which are pollinated, leading to the development of berries. Triggered by blossom showers.

procedures.details: Ensure adequate moisture in the soil before the expected flowering period. If natural blossom showers are insufficient, provide irrigation (at least 25mm) to induce flowering.
procedures.npk_dose: Apply 1/3rd of the NPK dose post-pruning or before expected blossom showers to promote flowering.
procedures.irrigation: Crucial for inducing flowering. Apply 25-50mm of water if natural rains fail.
procedures.pest_management: Maintain overall plant health. Avoid pesticide application during flowering to protect pollinators.

procedures.details: Apply a portion of the annual NPK fertilizer dose, emphasizing Phosphorus and Potassium, to support flower development and fruit set.
procedures.npk_dose: Apply 1/3rd of NPK recommendation (e.g., 50g N, 50g P2O5, 75g K2O per plant).
procedures.irrigation: Incorporate fertilizer and irrigate to facilitate absorption.
procedures.pest_management: Balanced nutrition supports robust flowering.

procedures.details: Coffee flowers are primarily self-pollinated, but cross-pollination by insects (bees) can enhance fruit set and bean development. Encourage beneficial insect populations.
procedures.irrigation: Maintain plant hydration for optimal flower opening and pollen viability.
procedures.pest_management: Avoid insecticidal sprays during flowering. Protect bees.

procedures.operation: Removal of Water Sprouts and Suckers
procedures.details: Remove any vegetative growth that emerges from the main stem or root collar, as these divert energy from flowering and fruit development.
procedures.irrigation: Not directly related, but plants should be healthy enough to withstand this operation.
procedures.pest_management: Ensure pruning tools are clean to prevent disease transmission.

procedures.details: Following successful pollination, small green berries begin to form. Monitor for signs of successful fruit set.
procedures.irrigation: Consistent moisture is vital for young berry development.
procedures.pest_management: Watch for early signs of pests like thrips affecting young berries.

procedures.details: Closely monitor for early symptoms of diseases like coffee leaf rust and pests that can affect flowers and young berries.
procedures.irrigation: Maintain optimal humidity and avoid conditions favoring disease development.
procedures.pest_management: Early detection and intervention are key. Copper sprays (0.5%) can be initiated as a preventive measure for leaf rust.

procedures.details: Ensure shade levels are optimal to protect delicate flowers and young berries from excessive sun scorch, especially for Arabica.
procedures.irrigation: Shade helps retain soil moisture, reducing irrigation needs.
procedures.pest_management: Not directly related.

procedures.details: Observe plant vigor and leaf color for any signs of nutrient deficiencies that might impact berry development.
procedures.irrigation: Nutrients are absorbed with water.
procedures.pest_management: Deficiency symptoms can mimic pest damage.

preventive_tips: Ensure adequate soil moisture before flowering.
Protect pollinators by avoiding pesticide application during flowering.
Monitor for early pest and disease symptoms.

lifecycle_phases.description: The longest phase where green berries enlarge, and the beans inside develop. Requires consistent moisture and nutrient supply.

procedures.details: Apply the second installment of NPK fertilizer to support the rapid growth of berries and bean development. Focus on Nitrogen and Potassium.
procedures.npk_dose: Apply 1/3rd of NPK recommendation (e.g., 50g N, 25g P2O5, 50g K2O per plant).
procedures.irrigation: Apply fertilizers with monsoon rains or follow with irrigation.
procedures.pest_management: Healthy nutrient supply boosts plant resilience.

procedures.details: Continue rigorous weed control, especially in the vicinity of young coffee plants, to minimize competition for nutrients and water.
procedures.irrigation: Weed-free conditions conserve moisture for coffee plants.
procedures.pest_management: Certain weeds can act as alternative hosts for pests and diseases.

procedures.details: Provide supplemental irrigation during dry spells, especially if rainfall is erratic. Maintain adequate soil moisture (around 40-50% available soil moisture).
procedures.irrigation: Drip irrigation is highly recommended for efficient water use (e.g., 2-3 times/week, 20-30 minutes per session).
procedures.pest_management: Avoid waterlogging, which can lead to root rot.

procedures.details: Monitor closely for White Stem Borer (WSB). Remove and destroy infested plants immediately. Apply trunk wash with systemic insecticides like Monocrotophos (0.05%) or Chlorpyriphos (0.07%) for preventive control, especially on young plants.
procedures.irrigation: Healthy plants are more resistant.
procedures.pest_management: WSB: Apply systemic insecticide trunk washes (e.g., Chlorpyriphos 0.07%) twice a year, ideally post-monsoon and pre-monsoon.

procedures.details: Implement timely prophylactic sprays of fungicides like Copper Oxychloride (0.3%) or Carbendazim (0.5g/L) to manage coffee leaf rust and coffee berry disease.
procedures.irrigation: Avoid overhead irrigation; ensure good air circulation.
procedures.pest_management: Coffee Leaf Rust: Spray Copper Oxychloride (0.3%) or Hexaconazole (0.05%) at 30-45 day intervals during the monsoon. Coffee Berry Disease: Spray Copper Oxychloride (0.3%) or Carbendazim (0.5g/L) during monsoon.

procedures.details: Continue pruning to maintain plant structure, remove unproductive wood, and ensure good light penetration and air circulation within the canopy.
procedures.irrigation: Proper pruning can influence water and nutrient distribution.
procedures.pest_management: Treat pruning wounds with a fungicide paste.

procedures.details: Adjust shade intensity if necessary. Excessive shade can lead to prolonged wetness on leaves and berries, increasing disease risk.
procedures.irrigation: Shade management impacts soil moisture levels.
procedures.pest_management: Not directly related.

procedures.details: If leaf analysis indicates deficiencies, apply micronutrient mixtures (e.g., Zinc, Boron, Magnesium) as foliar sprays.
procedures.npk_dose: Foliar application of micronutrient mixtures as per recommendations (e.g., Zinc Sulphate 0.2%, Borax 0.1%).
procedures.irrigation: Apply foliar sprays during cooler parts of the day.
procedures.pest_management: Nutrient-deficient plants are more susceptible to pests.

preventive_tips: Implement strict hygiene and sanitation practices.
Vigilant monitoring for White Stem Borer and Berry Borer.

lifecycle_phases.description: Berries transition from green to yellow, then red or crimson, indicating maturity and readiness for harvest. Sugar content increases, and bean quality develops.

procedures.details: Apply the final installment of NPK fertilizer to support bean development and maintain plant vigor during the ripening phase.
procedures.npk_dose: Apply the remaining 1/3rd of NPK recommendation (e.g., 70g N, 30g P2O5, 50g K2O per plant for mature plants).
procedures.irrigation: Incorporate fertilizers and irrigate to facilitate uptake.
procedures.pest_management: Adequate nutrition helps plants withstand the stress of ripening and harvesting.

procedures.details: Regularly inspect berries for uniform color change (red/crimson) and firmness, indicating peak ripeness.
procedures.irrigation: Avoid excessive watering during the final ripening stage, as it can lead to over-ripening or spoilage.
procedures.pest_management: Monitor for coffee berry borer infestation, which is more prevalent in ripening berries.

procedures.details: Clean harvesting equipment, pulping machinery (if applicable), and drying yards. Ensure sufficient labor is available.
procedures.irrigation: Not directly related.
procedures.pest_management: Clean equipment prevents contamination and post-harvest disease spread.

procedures.details: Begin selective picking of fully ripe berries ('fly picking') to ensure the highest quality. This is done before the main harvest.
procedures.irrigation: Not directly related.
procedures.pest_management: Harvesting ripe berries promptly reduces the risk of pest damage (e.g., berry borer).

procedures.details: Intensify monitoring for Coffee Berry Borer (CBB). Fallen berries and berries with exit holes are indicators of infestation.
procedures.irrigation: Not directly related.
procedures.pest_management: CBB: Harvest ripe berries promptly. If infestation is severe, consider post-harvest treatment or timely spraying with approved insecticides like Lambda-cyhalothrin (0.005%) on affected patches, avoiding near-harvest application if possible.

procedures.details: Avoid chemical sprays close to harvest to prevent residues. Focus on cultural practices and remove any diseased berries or leaves.
procedures.irrigation: Maintain good air circulation.
procedures.pest_management: Remove any remaining diseased berries/leaves to reduce inoculum for the next season.

procedures.details: Ensure shade is optimized to prevent over-ripening or sunscald on berries, while still protecting them from extreme heat.
procedures.irrigation: Not directly related.
procedures.pest_management: Not directly related.

procedures.details: Ensure plants have adequate nutrient reserves to support berry filling and maintain overall health.
procedures.irrigation: Water is crucial for nutrient translocation to the developing berries.
procedures.pest_management: Healthy plants resist pest attacks better.

preventive_tips: Prepare harvesting and processing infrastructure in advance.
Vigilantly scout for and manage coffee berry borer.
Avoid pesticide application close to harvest.
Maintain plant health through balanced nutrition.

lifecycle_phases.description: The process of picking ripe berries, followed by various methods of processing (wet or dry) to remove pulp and skin, and drying the beans to optimal moisture content.

procedures.details: Collect all ripe berries once the majority have reached the optimal red/crimson stage. This is usually done by hand picking.
procedures.irrigation: Avoid heavy watering just before harvest.
procedures.pest_management: Prompt harvesting reduces berry borer damage.

procedures.details: After main picking, strip remaining green and overripe berries from the branches. These are processed separately, often resulting in lower quality coffee.
procedures.irrigation: Not directly related.
procedures.pest_management: Stripping removes lingering pest hosts.

procedures.details: For wet processing, remove the outer skin and pulp from ripe cherries using a pulper. This is followed by fermentation to remove the mucilage layer.
procedures.irrigation: Water is extensively used in pulping and washing.
procedures.pest_management: Clean pulping machinery to prevent microbial contamination.

procedures.details: Ferment pulped coffee beans in tanks for 12-36 hours (depending on temperature and mucilage thickness) to break down the mucilage. Wash thoroughly afterwards.
procedures.irrigation: Water is used for washing.
procedures.pest_management: Monitor fermentation to avoid over-fermentation, which can cause defects.

procedures.details: For dry processing (natural process), spread harvested cherries in a single layer on drying patios or raised beds and dry them under the sun, raking regularly.
procedures.irrigation: Not applicable.
procedures.pest_management: Protect drying cherries from rain and dew. Turn regularly to ensure uniform drying and prevent mould growth.

procedures.details: Dry washed and fermented coffee beans (parchment coffee) on patios or raised beds until they reach the desired moisture content (10-12%).
procedures.irrigation: Not applicable.
procedures.pest_management: Ensure uniform drying to prevent mould and insect infestation during drying.

procedures.details: Once dried, parchment coffee is hulled to remove the parchment layer (hulling). Dry processed coffee beans are hulled to remove the skin. Beans are then graded by size and density.
procedures.irrigation: Not applicable.
procedures.pest_management: Clean milling equipment to avoid cross-contamination and maintain quality.

procedures.details: After harvest and drying, undertake pruning (e.g., 'javanica' pruning, single-stem pruning) to shape the bush, remove old wood, and encourage new growth for the next season. This is typically done during the dry season.
procedures.npk_dose: Apply FYM/compost (10-15 kg/plant) and base dose of NPK after pruning.
procedures.irrigation: Apply irrigation after pruning and manuring to help plants establish.
procedures.pest_management: Treat pruning wounds with Bordeaux paste or suitable fungicide to prevent disease entry.

preventive_tips: Maintain strict hygiene during pulping, fermentation, and washing.
Ensure uniform drying to 10-12% moisture content.
Protect drying beans from rain, dew, and direct intense sun.
Store dried beans in clean, dry conditions.

coffee_leaf_rust.name: Coffee Leaf Rust
symptoms: Small, yellowish-orange, powdery spots appear on the underside of leaves, usually starting on older leaves.
Spots enlarge and coalesce, turning reddish-brown.
Affected leaves may turn yellow, dry up, and fall prematurely, leading to defoliation.
In severe cases, twigs and branches may die back.
Yield reduction is significant due to premature leaf fall.
coffee_leaf_rust.favorable_conditions: Warm temperatures (20-28°C), high humidity (above 85%), intermittent rainfall, and prolonged periods of leaf wetness. Cloudy weather also favors its spread.
preventive_measures: Plant resistant varieties (e.g., Catimor, Hibrido de Timor, SLN series).
Maintain optimal shade levels (around 30-40% canopy cover for Arabica) to reduce leaf wetness duration.
Ensure proper spacing and canopy management for good air circulation.
Practice timely pruning and removal of infected leaves.
Maintain plant vigor through balanced nutrition and adequate irrigation.
Early detection and eradication of initial infections.

organic.application: Apply preventively before the onset of monsoon and repeat at 30-45 day intervals during the rainy season.

organic.dosage: 1% solution (10g Copper Sulphate + 10g Lime / L water)
organic.application: Apply pre-monsoon and during monsoon as needed.
Can be used as a supplementary measure, but less effective against established rust.

chemical.application: Systemic fungicide, effective against rust. Apply during monsoon or when disease appears.
Systemic fungicide with curative and protective action.
Effective systemic fungicide, particularly useful during severe outbreaks. Use in rotation with other fungicides.

black_rot.name: Black Rot (Koleroga)
symptoms: Affects leaves, twigs, and berries.
On leaves: Irregular, dark brown to black lesions, often starting at the tip or margin.
On twigs: Dark, sunken cankers, which can girdle and kill twigs.
On berries: Dark, sunken, circular spots that enlarge rapidly. Affected berries may shrivel, turn black, and drop.
In humid conditions, fungal structures may be visible as pinkish masses within lesions.
Severe infection leads to defoliation and die-back.
black_rot.favorable_conditions: High humidity, frequent rainfall, misty conditions, overcast skies, and warm temperatures (25-30°C). Often more severe during monsoon months.
preventive_measures: Proper centering and handling of bushes to allow sunlight penetration and air circulation.
Prompt removal and destruction of infected twigs, leaves, and berries.
Avoid overhead irrigation; use drip irrigation where possible.
Maintain plant vigor through balanced nutrition.
Prune out diseased branches and sterilize tools.
Ensure good drainage in the plantation.

organic.dosage: 1% solution (10g Copper Sulphate + 10g Lime / L water)
organic.application: Apply as a protective spray before the monsoon and repeat at monthly intervals during periods of high rainfall and humidity.
Effective against leaf and berry infections. Apply during monsoon.

chemical.application: Systemic fungicide. Apply as a foliar spray when disease is noticed and repeat if necessary.
Broad-spectrum protective fungicide. Apply during monsoon.
Systemic fungicide, effective against various Colletotrichum species.

coffee_berry_disease.name: Coffee Berry Disease (CBD)
symptoms: Primarily affects the berries, especially young, green berries.
Lesions start as small, dark, sunken spots, which enlarge rapidly.
Infected berries turn dark brown to black, often remaining firm and mummified on the tree.
Lesions may extend to cover the entire berry surface.
Severe infection leads to premature berry drop and significant crop loss.
Can also cause leaf spots and twig die-back under severe conditions.
coffee_berry_disease.favorable_conditions: High humidity, frequent rainfall, cool temperatures (18-22°C), and prolonged wetness on berries, especially during the period of berry expansion (typically monsoon months).
preventive_measures: Plant resistant varieties (though resistance varies).
Maintain optimal shade levels to regulate temperature and humidity.
Ensure good drainage and avoid waterlogging.
Prune bushes to improve air circulation and light penetration.
Promptly remove and destroy infected berries and plant debris.
Synchronize flowering and berry development where possible.
Apply recommended preventative fungicide sprays before and during the monsoon.

organic.application: Apply preventively at the start of the monsoon and repeat every 4-6 weeks during the high-risk period.

organic.dosage: 1% solution (10g Copper Sulphate + 10g Lime / L water)
organic.application: Use as a protective spray, particularly during periods of high rainfall.

chemical.application: Systemic fungicide. Effective when applied preventively or at the very early stages of infection. Requires careful timing.
Systemic fungicide that can be effective if applied timely.
Applied during critical periods of berry development and monsoon.

anthracnose.name: Anthracnose
symptoms: Affects leaves, twigs, and berries.
On leaves: Small, circular brown spots that enlarge and may develop concentric rings. In humid conditions, pinkish spore masses may appear.
On twigs: Die-back of young shoots.
On berries: Dark, sunken lesions on mature green or ripening berries. Can lead to premature drying and dropping of berries.
May cause 'pinholes' on beans during storage.
anthracnose.favorable_conditions: Warm, humid weather with prolonged leaf wetness and rainfall. Often occurs after periods of stress for the plant.
preventive_measures: Maintain plant vigor through balanced nutrition and adequate water supply.
Prune out infected twigs and branches.
Ensure good air circulation within the canopy.
Practice sanitation by removing fallen infected leaves and berries.
Avoid excessive damage to berries during handling.

organic.application: Apply preventively, especially during periods of high humidity and rainfall.

organic.dosage: 1% solution (10g Copper Sulphate + 10g Lime / L water)
organic.application: Protective spray during monsoon season.

chemical.application: Protective fungicide. Apply during monsoon and post-monsoon.
Systemic fungicide. Apply when symptoms are observed.
Systemic fungicide.

root_rot.name: Root Rot Complex
root_rot.scientific_name: Various fungi including Phytophthora spp., Pythium spp., Fusarium spp., Rhizoctonia solani
symptoms: Wilting of leaves, starting from the edges and progressing inwards.
Yellowing of leaves and premature defoliation.
Stunted growth and reduced vigor.
Poor flowering and fruit set.
In severe cases, the entire plant may die.
Affected roots are darkened, soft, and may be covered with fungal mycelia. The collar region may show dark, water-soaked lesions.
root_rot.favorable_conditions: Poorly drained soils, waterlogging, high soil moisture, compacted soils, excessive rainfall, and injury to roots or collar region. High temperatures can favor some pathogens.
preventive_measures: Ensure excellent drainage in the plantation (raised beds, contour planting).
Avoid over-irrigation and waterlogging.
Select planting sites with well-drained soils.
Use disease-free planting material.
Avoid mechanical injury to roots and collar during cultivation and manuring.
Apply Trichoderma viride (1 kg mixed with 50 kg FYM) to the soil annually.
Maintain balanced soil fertility.
Use soil solarization in nurseries before planting.

organic.dosage: Apply 1 kg mixed with 50 kg FYM or compost as soil drench around the base of infected plants.
organic.application: Primarily a preventive measure. Drenching can help suppress pathogen activity.
Drench around the collar region of affected plants.

chemical.application: Drench the soil around the base of infected plants. Repeat if necessary.
Systemic fungicide effective against Oomycetes. Drench the soil.
Effective soil fungicide. Apply as a drench.

white_stem_borer.name: White Stem Borer
symptoms: Presence of galleries/tunnels (long, winding) on the bark of the stem and larger branches, often filled with grub excreta (frass).
Small holes (exit holes) on the bark, especially on the lower part of the stem.
Yellowing of leaves, starting from the top downwards.
Drying and wilting of branches or the entire plant.
In severe infestations, the bark may peel off easily, revealing the galleries.
Adult beetles are typically seen during the monsoon months.
white_stem_borer.favorable_conditions: The pest is active during the monsoon season (June-September). Young, vigorous plants are more susceptible. Stress factors like drought or poor nutrition can increase susceptibility.
preventive_measures: Maintain healthy, vigorous plants through proper nutrition, irrigation, and shade management.
Avoid mechanical injury to the stem and bark.
Regularly inspect young plants (1-5 years old) for early signs of infestation.
Remove and destroy infested plants immediately.
Apply preventive trunk washes with recommended insecticides.
Timely pruning of dead and weak branches.

organic.application: Spray on the trunk and branches during the active adult emergence period (monsoon) to deter egg-laying.

organic.dosage: Wrap jute/hessian cloth around the base of the stem.
organic.application: Check for and remove larvae and pupae trapped in the banding material during dry periods.

chemical.application: Apply as a trunk wash covering the entire stem from the ground level up to the main branches. Apply twice a year, pre-monsoon (May-June) and post-monsoon (September-October).
Similar application as Chlorpyriphos. Use with caution.
Systemic insecticide. Can be applied as a trunk drench or spray.

coffee_berry_borer.name: Coffee Berry Borer
symptoms: Tiny exit holes (around 1 mm diameter) on the surface of green, ripening, or dried berries.
Presence of larvae and adults inside the berries.
Affected berries may shrivel, drop prematurely, or develop an unpleasant odor.
Damaged beans may have a 'punched' appearance and contribute to off-flavors in the brewed coffee.
coffee_berry_borer.favorable_conditions: Warm temperatures (around 20-30°C) and high humidity favor rapid reproduction. The pest is active throughout the year, with peak activity during ripening and drying stages.
preventive_measures: Harvest ripe berries promptly to reduce the time they are susceptible on the tree.
Practice thorough stripping of all remaining berries after the main harvest.
Ensure efficient drying of harvested cherries/parchment to below 12% moisture content.
Store dried coffee beans in clean, airtight containers or silos.
Remove and destroy fallen berries and debris from the plantation.
Maintain plant health to improve berry resilience.
Encourage natural enemies like the parasitoid Anagrus spp.

organic.application: Apply as a foliar spray during periods of high pest activity. May help deter egg-laying.
Apply as a foliar spray. The fungus infects the adult borers.

chemical.application: Contact insecticide. Apply carefully, especially during ripening, avoiding direct application close to harvest if possible. Focus on infested patches.
Contact insecticide. Used when infestation is severe.
Historically used, but due to environmental concerns, alternatives are preferred.

sucking_pests.name: Sucking Pests (Aphids, Mealybugs, Scales)
sucking_pests.scientific_name: Various species, e.g., Toxoptera aurantii (black coffee aphid), Planococcus spp. (mealybugs), Pulvinaria spp. (cottony cushion scale)
symptoms: Presence of insects on tender shoots, leaves, and berries.
Yellowing and distortion of leaves.
Stunted growth of shoots and berries.
Production of copious amounts of honeydew, leading to sooty mold growth (black covering on leaves and berries).
Mealybugs often cluster in leaf axils and on undersides of leaves.
Scales appear as small bumps attached to stems and leaves.
sucking_pests.favorable_conditions: Warm and dry weather often favors rapid multiplication. Mealybugs and scales thrive in sheltered locations. Ants often protect these pests, feeding on honeydew.
preventive_measures: Encourage natural enemies like ladybird beetles, lacewings, and parasitic wasps.
Maintain plant health through proper nutrition and water management.
Prune infested shoots and destroy them.
Control ant populations, as they often protect sucking pests.
Regularly monitor young plants and new flushes of growth.

organic.application: Spray thoroughly to cover infested parts. Repeat at 10-15 day intervals.
Direct contact spray. Effective against soft-bodied insects like aphids and mealybugs.
Can induce plant defense mechanisms and deter pests.

chemical.application: Systemic insecticide. Effective against a wide range of sucking pests. Apply as a foliar spray.
Contact and systemic action. Effective against aphids and scales.
Contact insecticide. Useful for quick knockdown of populations.

damping_off.name: Damping-off
damping_off.scientific_name: Pythium spp., Rhizoctonia solani, Fusarium spp.
symptoms: Seedlings collapse at the soil line and die.
A constricted, water-soaked lesion may be visible at the stem base.
Affected seedlings are easily pulled from the soil.
Can occur in pre-emergence (seeds rot before emerging) or post-emergence stages.
Often appears as patches of dead seedlings in the nursery bed.
damping_off.favorable_conditions: Cool, wet, and poorly drained soil conditions. High humidity. Overcrowding of seedlings. Use of infested soil or contaminated seed.
preventive_measures: Use sterilized soil and compost for nursery beds and polythene bags.
Ensure excellent drainage in nursery beds and bags.
Avoid overwatering and maintain optimal soil moisture.
Provide good ventilation and adequate sunlight.
Avoid sowing seeds too deep or too densely.
Practice crop rotation in nursery areas if possible.
Use seed treatment with fungicides.
Soil solarization of nursery beds before sowing.

organic.dosage: Mix thoroughly with soil/compost before filling bags or preparing beds (5-10g per kg of soil).
organic.application: Beneficial soil microorganism that antagonizes pathogens. Apply preventively.
Apply as a drench to the soil around seedlings at the first sign of infection.

chemical.application: Drench the soil in nursery beds or around seedlings. Repeat if necessary.
Apply as a soil drench or foliar spray at the first sign of disease.
Treat seeds before sowing to protect against seed-borne pathogens.
